step1.sentence: He wore out three pairs of running shoes during the training season.

step2.story: Chasing after her two-year-old twins all day wore her out completely. By seven o'clock, she was asleep on the couch before the children were.

step3.story: The hiking boots had served Tom faithfully for six years across mountains and city trails alike. He had re-soled them twice and stitched the laces back on once. But on a steep descent last autumn, the inner sole finally gave way and the boot was completely worn out. He held the boot in his hands for a moment before tossing it, feeling oddly grateful.

meaning.literalMeaningKo: 오래 사용하여 닳거나 낡다; 사람을 지치게 하다.
meaning.realUsageKo: 물건이 사용으로 인해 닳아 없어지거나, 사람이 완전히 지칠 때 씁니다.
meaning.etymologyKo: wear(닳게 하다)와 out(완전히)이 결합하여 완전히 닳아 버린다는 의미가 되었습니다.
meaning.nuanceKo: 물건의 마모와 사람의 피로 두 경우 모두에 씁니다. 완전히 닳거나 지쳐서 더 이상 못 쓰거나 못 움직인다는 느낌입니다.
meaning.shortExampleEn: The kids wore me out completely at the amusement park.
